results.content:
I am fully prepared to give this higher marks as I progress through the course, as the tutor is clearly enthusiastic. However, having reached the end of the 2nd video, my initial feedback as that most of the content so far has been 'death by powerpoint'. Full of hyperboled and subjective views, with little actual examples, and no visuals to help excite. This is not the best use of digital medium, and you may be losing a lot of potential customers who have a shorter attention span than I do (nearly everyone! :-) If this was a book, the cover would be plain brown paper. However, let's not judge the book by it's cover, and press on!

Update. I quit this course as i'm not convinced it teaches best practice - some of the stuff feels quite hacky. I went to Maximilian Schwarzmüller, as I think he has more expertise to instruct.

results.content:
Overall, the course meets my expectations, as I'm new to material-ui and I got all of the basics covered so far. As a beginner to material-ui, it's a great course. However, as I'm not a beginner to React overall, as soon as we start touching the logic, the level of outcome of this course drops a bit. The way of dealing with logic is somewhat too easy-going for me.
For example, the approach of using emails directly on a website is somewhat of a hurdle when you receive a ton of spam subsequently.  Also, the validation of the contact form is too simplified, as you could think that it would bother the user to see errors, as soon as you start typing, as well as the validation allows the user to type anything in the message and name fields - anything.

response.content: Thank you for such a thorough review, Kim! I really appreciate the feedback because it'll just help me refine my courses in the future. I did tend to take a relatively simple approach for most of the logic in this application because I didn't want to cloud the Material-UI and design concepts with lots of logic complexity. I really wanted to focus primarily on the building of interfaces with Material-UI, and not necessarily doing fancy stuff with React. I'm definitely interested in making a really rigorous full-stack course, though, so that might be something you see down the line!

results.content:
Reading through Material-UI documentation I can do on my own, for free :) 
Since I watched more than 10% I cant get refund, so here we go...
Instructor spends way to much time on MUI documentation. That alone would not be a problem if he try’s to explain docs or instruct on how to effectively use docs and not just go trough MUI examples. 
Overcomplicating simple things like if/switch branching indicates lack of basic programming experience. Section 3 in which navigation is developed, there are two 10+ minutes videos called Cleanup?! Well, he messed up cleanup too, replacing one overcomplicated code with another. To find solution for what he was trying to do, it took me 30 seconds youtube search. Nice 18 x 5 minute series replaces his two 3+hours long sections (total 6+hours!!!). This supposed to be Intermediate course on React and Material UI, but instructor lacks base React, React-Router knowledge, namely React-Router hooks ( useHistory, useLocation).
Since I cant get refund, i’ll probably go trough rest of course when I find 40 hours to waste, and update this review.

results.content:
I'm in the middle of the course ans maybe change my rating later but for now I have two major concerns about this course. Overall it's a nice course and I learned some new things about MU. But there are two downsides:
1. A lot of copy-paste and repetitive code. And by a lot I mean TONS of it. For now I've seen only header refactored, everything else is a copy paste with minimal changes. Maybe it will be refactored later in the course but from my point of view the structure of the the code is so transparent that implementation should have been cleaner from the start. A lot more react components and a lot less copy-paste.
2. 8+ hours dedicated to the Grid component. Grid is a simplest layout concept usually known to all interested in web development (ex. bootstrap uses similar system). But 1/3 of the course is just laying Grid after the Grid. No new material whatsoever. And it's highly repetitive due to first issue. 

But I really hope that the remaining of the course will give more information about MU.

response.content: Hi Elena, I really appreciate all the feedback you've given me here. One thing I am slightly confused about is you say there's a lot of copy-paste when we don't copy any paste anything, at every step in this course we write every line from scratch to create the application based on our design file. I think you might mean that we then copy and paste some of that code, but all the code is originally written from scratch and not just copy-pasted from somewhere else which is what you kinda make it sound like. That is a totally valid critique though, about having repetitive code. While recording the course I was mostly focused on MUI itself and the design, so I slipped a little on React best practices and DRY code. That's something I'll be improving upon heavily in all my future courses -- the code will be much more concise and programmatic. I would also like to add that we cover almost every single component in the MUI library in this course, so there should be plenty of new material especially for students who haven't ever worked with MUI before.

Zachary is an awesome teacher, no doubts. The voice and the audio quality are really nice. But the organization of the whole project, the architecture of the components are really awful and it makes really hard to continue with the course.

The level and understanding of React is quite bad, and some folks around here can learn this bad way and practices. I've tried to code while listening and viewing the classes, but I had to stop every second just to refactor and to create smaller and more manageable components. Please refactor this course because it makes me cry.... :( 

Such a good teacher but such a bad style of writing code in React.

response.content: Hi Dan, I really appreciate the thorough and honest feedback. That's a completely valid criticism of the course. When I was working on this course I was focused too much on the delivery and production, and focused on Material-UI and it's concepts rather than React best practices. I wanted to make the React side as simple as possible so people could just focus on learning Material-UI but I realize now that was taken too far to the extreme. All of my future courses will have a heavy emphasis on best practices to make the projects much more programmatic, concise, and reusable.

UPDATE to my prior review: Zachary was quick to follow-up on the two issues I raised. While correcting the video is difficult, he will be looking into providing access to code resources. The code plus using my browser following his explaining the Material-UI docs will overcome the two issues I listed. I'll add the 5th review star once Zachary provides the code resources.
_____________________________________________

This would be an excellent course — IF — two seriously needed corrections would be made:

1) The display of the instructor's code editor is illegible for students with normal 20/20 vision.  
2) The course needs downloadable resources ESPECIALLY since the display of the instructor's code editor is just way too small.

If these two issues are corrected, this course would easily be a 5+ star course simply because the instructor is articulate, explains the details behind each step, and clearly knows his subject.

Providing downloadable resources (issue #2, above) would be a giant step for improving the rating of the course. Solving this issue should be quick since it does not involve editing or reshooting the video lessons.

I hope to hear a reply from Zachary.

response.content: Hi Damir, I'm sorry you aren't enjoying the course. This has been very helpful for people who found the documentation to be somewhat confusing or hard to navigate on their own. I'm sure if you're very experienced and learn quickly then this may be tiresome for you, but I had to create the course with the widest audience in mind, not just the most advanced learners. That's also why I took my time to be thorough on all explanations. It seems like you're a quick learner so maybe watching the videos sped up will help you move through things at a more appropriate pace. I hope you consider the content of the course as a whole and update your review accordingly.

So far, this course is amazing, a true hidden gem. 

I have done several React courses but felt like many of them skip over integrating styling with React. This course has it all in one package. I find the concept of Material UI and how it is used with React is much more straight forward than styling with CSS. 
The instructor goes incredibly in-depth and doesn't just code and expect you to follow along, he goes through the MUI documentation and explains fully how to read & understand it. 

Brilliant course.

results.content: I'm just now in the beginning of this course and I LOOOOVE the  fact that we're taking the TIME to understand the WHY of things. WHY Material UI over these other options. I do not connect with courses or tutorials that just offer bullet, bullet, bullet, do this, do that, do this, do that and BOOM, you're finished. Without really having an understanding of the reason why you're doing this and that. I very much appreciate fundamentals or at least the first layer that underpins what I'm learning. It seems like this course is exactly set up for that. ALSO - I found this course because I was asking the EXACT same question as Zachary... where are is the in depth instruction on Material UI itself? I've been craving that and have found nothing outside of the (definitely) excellent documentation of Material UI. I've been wanting an actual course... and from what I've read in the description and seen so far, this is going to be just exactly what I've been needing. It will fill in the exact gaps I need it to.

response.content: Hi Monica! Thank you very much for such a genuine and thorough review! I definitely did my best to break things down to the basic concepts, so you'd have a foundation of true knowledge to build on and not just a memorized set of actions to repeat. I considered all of the conceptual questions I had when learning Material-UI for the first time, and tried to deliver everything from that perspective as closely as I could. There aren't very many guides on Material-UI out there so I was very happy to share this course with everyone on Udemy. I hope you continue enjoying the course, learn practical and applicable skills, and stay tuned for more!

response.content: Hi Shaukat, I'm sorry you haven't enjoyed the course so far. It seems like you haven't gotten very far into the course, though. We do cover a lot of information, which is why the course is 40 hours long. However, at the beginning we do a deep dive into the documentation to make sure students are comfortable with the concepts we apply when we go to build our project. We then build an entire production website, along with a second project at the end of the course, so the primary content of the course is project-driven with documentation walkthroughs for extra clarity. A lot of people find just the docs alone to be confusing, so many people have found these explanations helpful. I encourage you to continue throughout the course and I'm sure you'll find it to be extremely comprehensive and informative.
